awd_titl_txt: Phase II: New Infrared Detectors for Astrophysics
awd_abstract_narration:
Continuing a close cooperation between the Rochester Institute of Technology Center for Detectors and Raytheon Vision Systems, the PI will develop new infrared array detectors technology.  They plan to reduce the number of material defects (which is the major remaining barrier to using these devices in low light level applications required for astronomical instruments). If successful, this will enhance the capabilities of infrared instrumentation in astronomy by dramatically reducing cost, allowing for larger detectors, and potentially improving performance when compared to what is available with existing technology.  Beyond the astronomical community, this project could have positive impact on US technological competitiveness.  The PI will actively involve undergraduate and graduate students in all phases of this program at the interface of science and technology.

The PI and his team will continue development of a new material system for use in astronomical infrared array detectors. The devices use HgCdTe grown on Silicon using Molecular Beam Epitaxy. Preliminary results indicate that the technology will be successful for astronomy requirements pending further development.  In this second phase, a series of devices with improved design will be manufactured and tested. The approach is to reduce the number of material defects while maintaining high short-wavelength quantum efficiency. The proposed work includes: growth of new material using a thick buffer layer design, fabrication of twelve focal plane arrays in two designs, and extensive testing between the fabrication of the two designs.  This should enhance the capabilities of infrared instrumentation in astronomy by reducing cost and potentially improving performance when compared to what is available with existing technology.  The proposed plan features a tight connection between design at Raytheon Vision Systems and testing in the Center for Detectors at the Rochester Institute of Technology.

por.por_cntn:
The project team successfully advanced infrared detectors for astronomy by developing scalable and relatively inexpensive high performance detector using HgCdTe deposited onto silicon wafers. The team iterated the design with dozens of variations to optimize detector performance. Raytheon Vision Systems fabricated the devices and the Center for Detectors (CfD) at the Rochester Institute of Technology (RIT) characterized them. The characterization program included an extensive suite of tests in the laboratory and an on-sky validation program at a telescope. The telescope validation verified that the detectors have performance sufficient for typical astronomical photometry. The development effort has advanced the MCT on Si detector technology such that it is competitive with state-of-the-art commercially available infrared devices, particularly for wide-field survey applications on the ground, such as 2MASS, VISTA, and future ELTs. In conclusion, the best detectors developed in the project have performance that satisfies many ground-based astronomy applications, such as wide-field infrared imaging.
As part of this project, the CfD laboratory facilities have been significantly upgraded to continue the testing of state-of-the-art detectors over the coming decades. Light throughput and the experiment code base have been improved and modernized to increase the quality of future research data. The lab now has multiple testing systems for parallel testing of detectors, including radiation environment testing of project devices to prepare them for use in space.
